utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO- HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with our new Fox News contributor Emily Compagno, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5:00 in New York City and this is "The Five." President Trump taking his case for border security to the American people. In week three of the shutdown stalemate, the president is set to deliver his first prime time Oval Office address tomorrow night on what he's calling the, quote, "humanitarian and national security crisis on our southern border." And on Thursday, President Trump is heading to McAllen, Texas, to survey the situation on the ground and meet with immigration officials. The president also now saying he's willing to compromise on building a concrete wall and Trump isn't ruling out declaring a national emergency if Congress doesn't give him the necessary funding.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: They don't like concrete, so we will give them steel. Steel is actually more expensive than concrete, but it will look beautiful and it is very strong. It's actually stronger. We're looking at a national emergency because we have a national emergency. Just read the papers. It is national security. It's a national emergency.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Democrat congressman, Jerry Nadler, says he doubts the president will be truthful in his address to the nation tomorrow night.

utterances.speaker: REP. JERRY NADLER, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: The president has announced that he's going to address the country tomorrow night on the so-called crisis of the border. I expect the president to lie to the American people. Why do I expect this? Because he has been lying to the American people and his spokespeople continue to lie to the American people.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And Senator Lindsey Graham is slamming the, quote, "radical left," for refusing to negotiate with the GOP.

utterances.speaker: SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM, R-S.C.
utterances.utterance: As long as the radical left is in charge, we are never going to get anywhere. The president will compromise but he will not capitulate. So that's where we are at. I'm not going to negotiate with somebody who calls the Border Patrol agents a bunch of Nazis when they are trying to defend the border against a mob.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. I think we have to start with our newest Fox News contributor, Emily. Congratulations. We are glad that you are a contributor to Fox News. So, we'll give you the first shot of talking about the president making a decision to address the nation tomorrow night.

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, GUEST HOST, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Thank you so much. First of all, really, it is such an honor to be a part of this family so thank you guys.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO- HOST
utterances.utterance: You're welcome.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: So, I think what's important for me is for viewers to understand what it would look like if the president actually declared a national emergency and what that -- what trickles down from that. And basically, in the '70s, this act was passed. It was post-Watergate, it was post-Vietnam. And the main thing that he would have to do is cite a specific emergency provision, a specific emergency power, right, that activates what he's asking for. And so, there are hundreds of them by the way. There are hundreds of provisions under this act and he just has to specifically cite it. And underneath that, he gets extraordinary authority. He can take land. He can seize property. He can restrict travel, et cetera. And we are hearing already from the left and some of those comments things like, well you know, we are going to take this to court and this is just like the steel (ph) thing and it's not. It's totally separate. The only challengeable aspect would be whether that specificity is tied together, right? And the other thing that people should understand is that those specific provisions, there's monetary associations with it. So, if he went under the immigration act for example, that caps at $20 million. So really -- and there is a ton more options and what not, but basically a kind of overview would be cobbling together the money and the funding and whether that's in articulable (ph) specificity. And by the way, it pretty much is because, for example, under that immigration act, all that needs to happen is for him to cite the fact that the current resources are basically being stretched thin, they are not keeping up with it. So, there's that. And I also think -- on Representative Jeffries' comment about, well, we don't want to hold the American people hostage any longer over this medieval wall --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I also have that. Let's listen to that and then we will get you and Jesse to comment on this because he wanted to comment too. Do we have that montage please?

utterances.speaker: REP. HAKEEM JEFFRIES , D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: We need to actually reopen the government and stop holding the American people hostage simply because Donald Trump wants a medieval border wall.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHRIS COONS, D-DEL.
utterances.utterance: A fourth century concrete wall that you can't see through will be a less effective border barrier.

utterances.speaker: SEN. JEFF MERKLEY, D-ORE.
utterances.utterance: Let's spend the citizens' money in a smart fashion, not with some fourth century basically pointless strategy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The fourth century talking point has gone out, the signal.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes and here's my point. He said that that holds us hostage right now, there's the standoff. We are already held hostage. We are held hostage throughout the entire nation right now with everything that is coming over the southern border and how it impacts all aspects of the criminal justice system. It's not just the drugs coming across or migrants seeking asylum. It goes so much deeper than that. When we have -- what's the currency of all the gangs riddling in these cities? It is drugs. What are -- how are the sheriff's prevent it? How are the, you know, relations between ICE, et cetera. It's multi-layers.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It is indeed. What do you think about the fourth century comment?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, he's not using leeches at the southern border. He's using proven security techniques.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Not yet, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, just wait. Listen, a lot of things are useful that have been used for very long time from medieval times, shackles, blades, men on horseback, prisons, shields, you know, those things are useful because they work.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Some of your favorite things, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Some of the things in Gutfeld's basement. So, you know, the president likes to use the analogy of the wheel. The wheel works over time and it's because it's effective, just like walls are effective. I don't like how Nadler is saying that the president is going to lie tomorrow night. The president has told the truth on the caravan from the beginning. He said it was mostly men, not a bunch of women and children. The men were looking for money, not asylum. And what happened when the caravan finally reached the southern border? Uptick 300 percent in violence perpetrated against the border agents. If anything the president has compromised and moderated his position, if you look at he's offering out $800 million for humanitarian situation. He is saying now we want a steel fence. The steel fence has been voted on positively by Democrats in the past. It's an environmentally friendly. Water can just trickle through it. It helps the U.S. steel industry as well. People can see through it so they have visibility on the other side. A lot of these things that the president is doing is trying to bring Nancy Pelosi to the negotiating table. If anything, Nancy looks like the one stuck in the mud.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But Juan, I do think that the Democrats seem vulnerable on that point, that they did vote for secure fencing in the past and does it really matter if it is steel or concrete?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: No, this whole thing is a manufactured, you know, political --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: From both sides?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, from the -- Trump is the one who has created this. The Democrats didn't create this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But my question was they voted in the past for secure fencing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, in order for border security. I mean, unless -- I mean, if the argument is Democrats don't click here on border security that is patently false. This whole thing though is striking to me and that the only way to understand it is that Trump is playing base, tribal politics. Most independents don't support it. Obviously, most Democrats don't support it. There is no national emergency. You can go back to the midterms. There was -- remember, we were being invaded. Now, it looks like there was no invasion. It was a bunch of desperate people. At the moment, he says, oh, there are all these criminals coming over. If you watch Fox News Sunday yesterday, Chris Wallace absolutely dismantled Sarah Huckabee Sanders on this point. There is no evidence, even from Trump's own Justice Department, his own immigration services. So, he is doing this for some political reason, and it's not quite clear what it is except to me, to distract from his own problems with Wall Street going on to us, the failure to enact an asylum ban, to the problems that he has with John Bolton contradicting him about the pullout in Syria.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There is plenty that we can talk about. But let's talk -- let's stick on this. So the president is going to address the nation tomorrow night. Can he address all those things that Juan is saying for independents that might not be on board?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I think he should address the crux of the argument of the Democrats when they are constantly saying walls are immoral, OK. That's the whole point and that's kind of like what everybody is saying. It's horrible. It's immoral. Well, what about the walls that we already have then? Should we ask Nancy Pelosi about removing the walls that we already have on the border because there are walls on the border. This stance is so weak. You could blow it over with a sneeze. And also, I know -- Juan always keeps saying, oh, it's appealing to the base. Essentially, that's what politics is, is you are appealing to the people who voted for you and he made a promise that he was going to build a wall. It might have put him in a corner, it might, but he has to actually address it because no one really addressed it in this way before. The fact is the Democrats agree with him on everything and the only reason why they won't do it is because it's him. So the bottom line is, it's a personal vendetta. And President Trump tomorrow should talk about the wall but also to talk about the personal vendetta and say look, hey, clearly, the Democrats were for this but they don't like me so I'm going to step out of this. I want somebody else to take charge of this. I will step out of the room so you guys -- I don't want the credit. I will step out of here. You get the engineers involved because you just heard Schumer say that it's not so much about the money now. It's the fact that they don't have a plan. Well, that's the step. So now you come up with a plan with the engineers involved.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Ask the experts what they need.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Ask the experts what they need, but I'm going to step out of this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's what you said, you wanted Dr. Phil to be the expert.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, Dr. Drew, not Dr. Phil.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Dr. Drew, sorry. No offense.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- call him Dr. Frankenstein. But I just want to say to you, if that's the case, if it's just about the way you post it, Trump hatred, well how come we had two years of a Republican majority in the House and the Senate and Trump and the White House, didn't get done? How come we have a situation --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because you need 60 votes in the Senate, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- Trump says the Mexicans will pay for this wall. I don't see that. How about he says the wall is being built and there's no wall. He keeps lying and you guys keep buying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I'm not buying anything, but I will say this. I do love a stalemate. And I'll tell you why because I like slow government. I am like a slow cooker. So I'm OK with this going on and the thing is -- and here's this -- one of -- here's an interesting truth. What if you threw a government shutdown and nobody came? I mean, it really is interesting. We sit here and we go, it's day 14 or its third week.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I want to hike in the national parks tomorrow and I can't.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I really need a good hike.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You do. I've seen you put on weight.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How about 800,000 people who don't get paid plus, I guess, 40,000 contractors. Those are real people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, but the real people that -- if you look at employment across the board, Juan, it's been an amazing achievement across the board.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So we should punish these people? I don't think that's fair.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I'm not saying that. I'm saying that there is something to get with the pluses and the minuses, and right now, Trump, this is it. This is a shutdown that is happening after -- I hear you, we have to go (ph).

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I say Juan doesn't get paid during the shutdown. Can we agree on that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Give me your money buddy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. We're going to go. Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio- Cortez making tons of headlines and creating a new controversy. Greg's take, up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: AOC was on "60 Minutes" last night, quite a feat for a newcomer, must be all her great new ideas.

utterances.speaker: REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: People are going to have to start paying their fair share in taxes. Once you get to like the tippy top, on your $10 millionth, sometimes you see tax rates as high as 60 or 70 percent.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What an expression. Now, the real story is in AOC's very old ideas. It's the media's gushy view of her. Even with her old ideas, she gets on "60 Minutes." The past is called the future and you better love it. Take AOC's delightful dancing video from last week. The media created a fake story that conservatives attacked her over this delightful trifle. Not really. In fact, the only stories written about the dance were by liberals using it to falsely smear the right. So the press creates a shield around her, in which any criticism must be due to sexism or bigotry, when in fact, it is in their heads and not ours. But the strategy works by preventing real criticism about her actual beliefs, which are retreads of horrible ideas from previous centuries, socialism with a smile, fascism among friends, Venezuela meets vegan. The sad news is that we have proof of such utopian nightmares. Sadder news, so many young people don't care. Socialism is a brand that happily reinvents itself with every naive generation. AOC's fans like to say she is living in our heads like Pharrell Williams singing "Happy." But in fact, it's the policies that live in our heads, and they should live there because we know so many people who have been brutalized by such ideas. When you hear someone talk about socialism like it's a fun new way to pay down my college debt, you've got to scream. Just prepare to be called awful things for doing so. Today, pointing out the evil of the past makes you the bane of the present. You know, Jesse, you know that I love? Here's the left, suddenly they want to return to the 1950s.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a great point. I mean, all of her ideas are displayed on the socialist playbook. I do think she's very talented on social media and she's got a big following, but she's now a member of Congress as a Democrat and there are certain rules as a Democrat that you have to play by. Now, she's just a freshman. She has to realize Pinocchios are for Donald Trump. She can't be so sloppy she's getting fact-checked all the time by "The Washington Post."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Slow down. Did you really, I mean, you are putting her down by comparing her to Trump?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I am saying that the only reason she --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, she is complementing her.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, he said Pinocchio. That means she's lying like Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, when "The Washington Post" fact checks her more than Donald Trump, it's a problem for the Democrats. Also, she's also so out there politically that the Republicans can now use her as a wedge issue against their own party and the leadership hates that. She is also hot-dogging Nancy Pelosi. She is starting to steal her thunder and a lot of people in leadership are saying, hey, slow down a little bit. Let's be honest. This reminds me of a rookie, you know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Got a great college career, now they got drafted, top draft, picked, they entered the league, and given the opposite -- opposing teams a lot of bulletin board material, kind of bad with chemistry in the locker room, a lot of the vets on the team don't really like her that much, getting called for a lot of personal fouls in the field. The coaches are a little --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Are you talking about her?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFERLD
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, we love --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I would never.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- rookie --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm saying she's in page six a lot. You know, she might burn out but she might have a long career. We don't really know yet.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Jesse, let me just point some things at you. One, she voted for Nancy Pelosi and then the Republicans hissed at her because guess what, she is gold for Republicans. They are making her the star.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not really.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: More of the Democrats. It's Republicans who love her because she represents --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Republicans didn't put her on "60 Minutes."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think they did because they gave her so much attention that "60 Minutes" said, wow, who is this woman?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Oh my god.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She is wrong a lot of the time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What is she wrong about?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Everything that she has advocated as a policy, 70 percent tax rate, social security, universal healthcare.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Social security? How about that? Remember when that was radical? Oh, yes, great society. Terrible. What about raising tax rates? Under President Roosevelt, President Eisenhower --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, Juan, if you want to throw in with the 70 percent tax rate, you can check that box on the return and voluntarily pay it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: If you make more than 10 million and if you have no objections to the fact that under Trump right now the deficit is blowing sky-high. You don't even mention it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You will never get 10 million if you have policies like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: By the way, the rich pay now more than ever. I think the top one percent pays 40 percent total tax. In 1980, it was 19 percent. So, it's gotten a lot worse and it's not actually affecting the debt whatsoever. I want to go to this interesting thing --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Why do you say that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It doesn't have -- we are still in -- we're still in totally in debt.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The deficit has been increasing radically.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's my point. It doesn't matter how much you tax people. In fact, I have argued stop taxing people. It doesn't matter because we are spending addicts, right. If you stop -- if you stop taxing our country for one year, it would bloom with $4 trillion? Would we even care? That would be great. We'd all may save all of our money and we'd be in debt but we don't care.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We live in anarchy, you would love that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's an anarchy. All right, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, one thing I've noticed just a comparison and the correlation to Donald Trump, AOC comes in and calls out the establishment Democrats. You got Whoopi Goldberg on "The View," saying, hold your horses, lady. There were a bunch of Democrats before you, there are thousands (ph) of Democrats who worked their butts off to get this and that. Isn't that a pretty fair course (ph)?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: People that we're voting for Democrats in deep blue districts like AOC, were definitely saying that, that they are done with the status (ph). We've been thinking a lot of Bernie Bros.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Bernie Bros wanted something -- they didn't want Hillary Clinton. Hillary Clinton didn't win because there are not enough Democrats who wanted her to come out and win. I knew that Nancy Pelosi at some point would be eclipsed by this younger generation. I just didn't know it will happen in three days. That's pretty interesting. The other thing is, AOC beat one of Pelosi's most ardent allies in the Congress. She owes Pelosi nothing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And yes, she -- but I do think, Jesse makes a great point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let that sink in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Everybody went quiet.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Even I did.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It came out of your mouth.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- the more she actually talks about the ideas, not her personally, not the dance and all of that, but the ideas, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That you could retrofit all of America within 10 years with renewable energy. Policy wise, you have to go, OK, that's not possible and she would say, why not just say it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Every day she has got a build the wall comment, right? She goes way -- she goes forward, Emily, every time. I think the upside is when she's talking about like socialism in Sweden or she's talking about 70 percent rates, it reminds other people to go read up on this stuff and find out the truth.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Totally, which in Sweden, it's a violent reality. Sweden is absolutely going down in flames, those parallel societies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sweden? (Inaudible).

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: (Inaudible), that's true. I got to give Greg one.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: The violent crimes there have risen by 40 percent.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We got zero, it is nothing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: If I mug Greg, it's suddenly like 100 percent jump in crime. Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: -- wants to take this up further, I think the use of as analogy a culturally, formerly homogenous society in a tiny country is not accurate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: It's applicable here. That's kind of ridiculous. And I think for AOC, her time to be popular is over. Now is her time to get to work. She already won. So there, I think like everyone, we could benefit from specificity and accuracy in Congress. So, it would only help her further and further her cause and the people that could rally behind -- even if she doesn't -- isn't owed anything by anyone or she doesn't owe, I think there's a certain amount of homage she should pay by being specific and accurate and not so --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I wonder if she has going -- everybody wants to have a beer with her.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, Elizabeth Warren with a new spin on her disastrous DNA test and Joe Biden's 2020 plans, that's next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The Democrats race for the White House underway in January. Joe Biden may be nearing his decision, the former vice president reportedly set to decide within the next two weeks if he's going to run. Biden's allies and Biden himself saying he is the party's best hope. Bernie Sanders being snubbed by his hometown newspaper, the editorial board of the Vermont paper begging the senator to not run for president again. And Elizabeth warren taking her pitch to Iowa over the weekend, the potential 2020 hopeful hitting the key battleground state where she defended her decision to take a DNA test.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN, D-MASS.
utterances.utterance: I am not a person of color. I'm not a citizen of a tribe. Tribal citizenship is very different from ancestry. Tribes and only tribes determine tribal citizenship, and I respect that difference.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, I am a guy who loves a joke especially at the start of the year. And so I thought, let me start with Greg and Pocahontas. How can that loose, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, the funny thing is, is she's trying to reduce her fib with a little bit of a diversion. She is saying -- she is started talking about how she didn't say she was -- and I realized now that ancestry is different than a tribe. And now that she gets it, but that's not what she's guilty of. She used Native-American claims to gain an edge over other people in teaching positions at Harvard. It was -- she notified them and put that in the directory and comically she also used her Cherokee background for a cookbook in which may be she lifted those recipes from "The New York Times."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Pow Wow Chow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Pow Wow Chow. Did we talk about Biden?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I mentioned him but I -- go right ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, so Biden endorsed himself -- did you see this?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: By saying he doesn't see anybody better and that reminded me of when I go into a really weird Skivvy (ph) bar and I ordered the chicken fingers because how can they ruin chicken fingers? He is like saying I am the least and probably the least bad meal in this restaurant.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Safe.

utterances.speaker: GUTELD
utterances.utterance: It's a --- he is endorsing -- he barely endorsed himself.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It doesn't really scream excitement without --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, vote for me. I am the least worst thing on the menu.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I mean, it sounds so Trumpian.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, Trump, he said he was better than everybody else and what do you got to lose?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Dana, so they have another poll out, Des Moines Register and CNN, and for the second time they say Biden is the top candidate.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I just think that all of these polls right now are only about name ID. So, I think -- so, she got what she wanted, right. So she wanted to be first so that she could get some headlines. And the problem is she's grounding the rationale for her candidacy in her personal story, which goes back to her hardscrabble roots in Oklahoma, which inevitably it's not that that media asked her questions about her ancestry. That was from a member of the audience, somebody from Iowa who really wanted to know. So I don't know if she can shake it in terms of getting that story off of her tail. But it will be --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tail?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I know. I don't know. Shake it -- I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Shake it off her tail? Is that some kind of weird --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I have jet lag. That's my only excuse. But --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm going to try that one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Don't do that. Don't do that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm going to give it to Jesse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Can she shake it off her tail, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Hey, Jesse, I have an interesting one, though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What if Trump's not the Republican nominee? What if it's someone like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Mitt Romney?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- let's say Mitt Romney or Jeff Flake. Then what are the Democrats to do?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What? Right now?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's going to be Jeff Flake, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm just asking. Because you never know what happens in 2019.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I don't see that. I think Trump is going to get the nomination. I think Biden knows he can't win; and he's been hemming and hawing and donors like -- donors don't like him that much. And I don't think he has the stomach to fight it out with other Democrats, being an old, straight, white male, this time around. He knows that it's going to devolve into an insult fest, if he does get the nomination, with Donald Trump. The race would be about the pasts, not the future. And he's never really had a natural base in politics. That's why Trump called him 1 Percent Joe.

utterances.speaker: On -- I wouldn't call her Pocahontas. I'd call her Elizabeth Warren. But you remember, Juan
utterances.utterance: We did the DNA test. I am more black than she is Native American.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm more Native American than she is, and my last name is Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Come on!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So that would be like if I wrote a soul food cookbook and said that, you know, "Jesse Watters, black person." Like, that's what she did. She wrote "Powwow Chow, Native American Cherokee, Elizabeth Warren."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Could you imagine the hell I'd catch if I did that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. You'd get it right here on "The Five." But I must say, I don't think it was Elizabeth Warren who advanced -- I mean, you guys were saying she advanced her career. I think Harvard put her down in that way.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They used each other. They used each other. Harvard used her, and she used Harvard.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the way, you know, Bernie Sanders is 77. I think Biden is 76 or something like that. Elizabeth Warren, Emily, 69. So it's not like -- and they're all white. So I don't get what you guys are -- "Oh, the problem is that they're white." I don't see that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think to answer, respond to the last point, I think for the Democrats championing the fact that the GOP right now and Trump is full of racism and that it's the, you know, party of white men, then to offer only a white man, for example, for Biden, saying, "I'm the most qualified person to represent this entire party" and all these people of color and all these other colorful people that he's supposed to represent. Like, to me, that's a huge disconnect. Who does he think he is to do that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He was vice president twice, and he was in the Senate forever.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: So why should that experience automatically lend itself and his failed prior campaigns, as well, to represent all of these people whose voices now recently have -- have become louder? And people are saying, "Give me a seat at the table, too." So I just think there's a certain, like, hubris associated with it, and he just rubs me the wrong way. And obviously --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He rubs a lot of people.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: And for that aspect, too. And Elizabeth Warren is obviously the most unrelatable person, and that video is just ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Did he rub any tails the wrong way? We'll see.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He probably did.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Is the coverage of the president not negative enough? What a New York Times writer is arguing, straight ahead on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Very nice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's Beethoven's Fifth, for you guys keeping score at home. Bring a little more refinement to "The Five." New York Times columnist Frank Bruni is defending the media's overwhelming negative coverage of President Trump and says the press should be even tougher on him.

utterances.speaker: BRIAN STELTER, CNN CHIEF MEDIA CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: This idea that the new coverage is negative, is too negative, where's the truth behind it?

utterances.speaker: FRANK BRUNI, COLUMNIST, NEW YORK TIMES
utterances.utterance: I disagree wholeheartedly with that. He's a singular president. He was a singular candidate. No one has lied like him. "Anti-Trump" connotes driven by some kind of animus regardless of the facts. I don't think we've been anti-Trump. I think we have been negative, and I think that's the only honest way to cover this president.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wow. This comes as the president ramps up his attacks on the media, blasting them on Twitter as, quote, "crazed lunatics." Emily, I don't have a problem with media covering the president negatively. I think that's fine. But they should also point out when there are positive achievements coming out of this White House.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I agree with you 100 percent, except I will say that, for the defense of the coverage, to say, "Well, we're going to be consistently negatively covering the president, because that's all he deserves," well, what do we deserve? What do the people deserve? Meaning cover the office, then. Cover the executive branch. Cover the legislator -- legislature. Give us more specificity again, like I always talk about, so that it's not just dumping on the president. Let's honor the office a little bit more, because that trickles down, too. And you know, we saw that -- that coverage consistently for the last few years has been 90 percent negative and 37 percent dedicated to policy and then 63 percent scandals. And I think there's a lot of comments out there, as well, with FOX News coverage. And now, we're hearing, "Well, that's -- that's a negative based" -- what did he say? He said a mocking and sneering tone, not just of opinion but also of the actual coverage. So I think the spectrum goes, certainly, both ways.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, don't you think, if this were a Democrat president and the ISIS caliphate have been destroyed and wage growth was up best it has been in a decade, and you're going to reach 3 percent GDP growth this year, and NAFTA had been renegotiated after there had been promised to be renegotiated for two decades, don't you think the coverage would be a little more positive?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. If a Democrat lied as much as this guy?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I'm saying if he had accomplished as much is this guy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, you talked about NAFTA. Basically, there's no change, in whatever they call it now, U.S., Mexico --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: MCA.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: MCA. There's no -- there's basically no change. OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And then you say ISIS --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's not true, but go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: ISIS destroyed. Even the president now and Bolton are saying, "Well, no, not quite. We're going to have to protect the Kurds, et cetera." So it's all, like -- it's exaggerate -- I don't know how a legitimate reporter is supposed to get away from the -- from being attacked as being too negative when you're just saying this is what's going on in America.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is what the president -- Mitt Romney said the same thing last week.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. So Juan thinks the coverage is fair, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: One of the things that's interesting is as I was watching that over the weekend, I said it reminded me of the media that was, you know, self-flagellating after the invasion of Iraq, saying, "We should have vetted it more. We should have been more careful. We shouldn't have gotten caught up in it." Well, during the campaign, the -- all the media was giving President Trump a lot of attention. And it wasn't all negative. Ask Hillary Clinton. Right? She would say that The New York Time, in particular, Clinton Global Initiative, her emails, she was very frustrated with them. The other thing is the media is, like, the only industry that grades itself. And it's a constant self-grading. Every other industry, the media is looking at you. So Facebook and Silicon Valley --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- is under pressure. Pharmaceuticals companies under pressure, oil companies under pressure. The media is only -- they're not under pressure from anyone else. So getting the --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Except Trump.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's the only one who pushes back.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- that pushback. Yes, they're getting that pushback. This was really the first time they've ever really had to do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And they're a little sensitive about that, Greg. That's why they have to justify the coverage all the time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think, No. 1, Bruni was upset over all the news that Jill Abramson got, when she admitted the truth, which is that dumping on Trump is big business, and business is booming. And I always use the restaurant metaphor, that all media right now, every one of us is now a restaurant; and we're all serving Trump burgers, because you can't serve it enough. Whether you love Trump, you'll sit and listen. Whether you hate Trump, you'll sit and listen. So he was hypersensitive. But there's a leftist principle also behind his statement, and that is "If I believe that you are immoral, if I believe that Donald Trump is immoral and that his followers or his supporters are immoral, then I don't have to play fair. I don't have to be an objective journalist anymore. I don't have to be objective in my headlines or on the front page." Opinion journalism can then infect every area, which is really convenient for them. Because the right, we think you're wrong. Juan, we think you're wrong, but we'll debate and engage. But the left thinks you're evil, so they don't have to. And that's incredibly convenient for them to justify what he just said, which is that our biases are moral, OK, so we can say whatever you want before -- about Trump. But the fact is, those biases existed before Trump. They hate everybody outside of New York. Outside of the cities. What you like, they hate, and because you like Trump, they hate you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How do you like --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is the contrast between how the media is portraying Trump versus when you talk to somebody on the street about Trump is so vast. When you seem you have low unemployment records. Men, women, minorities, and teens. Teen unemployment is down. Optimism has never been higher. So you're on two different planets here. You talk to this guy, he says the world is ending. You talk to the world, they're saying things are going pretty good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How do you like your Trump burger?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I like it medium well with a lot of ketchup.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think he likes it with a wall built in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, a wall of fries.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Better than the taco bowl?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, I miss the taco bowl. Remember that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think -- I think he sells it with a lot of sizzle, not much meat. Where's the burger?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, Juan. We're chasing you out of the restaurant. Coming up, Kevin Spacey's bizarre court appearance to face a sexual assault allegation. Up next.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Actor Kevin Spacey made his first appearance in a Massachusetts court room today. The two-time Oscar-winner facing a sex assault charge for allegedly groping an 18-year-old man at a Nantucket bar in 2016. He pled not guilty and was ordered to not have contact with his accuser. The next court date is set for March 4. All right. So Juan, I'm going to start with you. Over 30 men have come out and accused Kevin Spacey of some type of sexual misconduct. Is this the one where he's going to face a reckoning?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I guess we have to see what -- what comes of it. I mean, what's so interesting to me about this case is that he went, Emily, on video. And he did this video where he pretends to be the character out of "House of Cards," Frank Underwood. I think the video is called "Let Me Be Frank." And then he starts saying, "Oh, if it was only so simple. Everybody wants me to be guilty. People are assuming this and assuming that, and the whole story hasn't come out." To be fair to him, let the story come out. But wow, what you just said is telling. So it's not only in the U.S., this case up in Massachusetts. But you also have people in London, where he was the artistic director at a theater there, saying that over a span of 20 years, he was guilty of such behavior. So these allegations now touch so many parts of his life and career that he's been -- not only was he canceled out of "House of Cards," but he lost the opportunity to be in a biopic about Gore Vidal. And he's lost other opportunities. And, you know, we'll see what comes of it. I'm just stunned that he's only the second man to be criminally charged in all we've heard from the #MeToo movement.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Right. And on that video, that was -- the same day that he released it was the day, actually, that the D.A. there announced those charges in Nantucket. What did you make of his demeanor in court today?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He seemed cocky and detached. Looks like a guy that knows he's going to beat the rap. Most rich guys do, especially Hollywood stars.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Don't tell Bill Cosby.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's true. It's true, Juan, you're right. I mean, we've learned a few things from the #MeToo movement. One: men in positions of power can abuse their authority. and industries can protect them in order to protect the bottom line. But also, two, he's innocent until he's proven guilty. And you've got to follow the facts. And in this case, it's going to be adjudicated in the courtroom, not the court of public opinion. So that's a good thing. Usually in cases like this, you need eyewitness testimony. You need some sort of video surveillance. We're hearing there's a Snapchat video involved of him using his hands to touch someone. But, you know, traditionally, guys like this will skate on a -- on a situation like this. But you know, I'll just follow the case, and I'll decide afterwards.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Dana, we already heard -- we heard today in court that there are attorneys asking to preserve the record, the cell phone record.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: So do we think that's already setting up for, basically, a victim shaming approach?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, perhaps. I talked to a friend from Boston, and they said -- is it Mitchell Garabedian. I think that's how you say his name. That his presence on the case apparently will mean that there's a lot of headlines in this case. He was part of the Boston clergy defense and so there -- just he gets a lot of media. So that will be part of it. But this is also the first time a high-profile gay celebrity has been targeted in the #MeToo movement. And I don't know exactly where it will go. Just obviously, I don't know. The Frank Underwood video, I don't know -- again, I feel like it's all part of a P.R. strategy and it's perhaps something that his lawyer suggested that he do.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Greg, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't think anybody suggested him to do that. That was so -- this is why -- I mean, you know, obviously, this is the hard thing about this topic, because we don't know. It's the first day. We have no information. I don't think he will -- he will be found guilty on this, precisely because of that bizarre video. He's acting like someone who's not guilty.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The way he acted in that courtroom is he knows. There's something else going on there. And when the lawyer asked about Bubble over the email stuff, it leads me to believe that there's some kind of correspondence that's going on there that may still -- that may exonerate him. But again, I don't know. I think a person can be guilty of many things, which he probably is, but also be a victim of scapegoating --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- when the system itself was aware and implicitly condoned his behavior, the behavior of many men for 100 years. Let's say Hollywood has been around for 100 years. They condoned, they allowed this behavior to take place. But so now in the #MeToo era, you must sacrifice the most well-known offenders to this funeral pyre or whatever it is. No question he's a sexual boor. The -- B-O -- what's the boor?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: B-O-O-R.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: B-O-O-R. It's not that he's boring. But what I'm saying is that I think right now -- I think right now, he could be innocent of this but be guilty of other things.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's time now for "One More Thing." So I'll go first. I missed you all last week. I went on a little trip with friends and family. We went to Kenya, and it was a great trip. We were in Nairobi and visited this orphanage and school, the Thomas Barnardo House. We did a little career day assembly with those kids, and they could ask us all sorts of questions. We had a barbecue, and they were out. There was dancing, as you can see. They were trying to teach us to dance. We were not very good. We were giving it our best shot. And then, my young friend -- and Greg knows her, too -- Macy English, there you see her. She's 14. And she's with these other 14-year-old girls, finding out that, you know, they have the same concerns, problems, hopes and dreams as any other kids. And I saw giraffes and elephants and lions on the safari part of our trip.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Great picture.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I tries to do a selfie with the giraffe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A forehead.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'll have more things to show later on in the week. That was the lion. That was the big catch that we saw. We didn't catch them; we just looked at him. Very respectfully, of course. Kenya does a great job of conservation. It was a wonderful trip. Highly recommend it. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That was awesome. Well, the Christmas lights are still up all over town, but the holiday is over for me. And while it's great to be back at work, the memories are still fresh. Here I am on Christmas day with my wife, Delise, wearing the suit that Jesse gave me for Christmas --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- because I'm a snowflake.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Sharp.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Then it was off to Jamaica. Here we are at the airport in matching running suits.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And here are my grandkids on a boat that took us snorkeling, having fun. Here's Delise relaxing, and here I am hanging out with my wife at the pool. Here are my three grandkids having some fun in the sun, and here I am giving a big hug to my youngest son, Raffi. It was that kind of vacation, full of fun. But a delight to be back here at work.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Indeed. All right, Jesse, what do you have. Something good? Something funny?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, not funny. Eagles pulled off a miraculous win against Chicago at Soldier Field. Look at this. Nick Foles, under a minute left, throws a little out to Golden Tate, who we acquired midseason. I'd think that played off pretty well right there for the go-ahead score. They didn't get the two-point diversion. So they're down -- they're up one. This is Cody Parkey lining up. I think it's, like, a 42-yard field goal. I wanted to, guys -- show you guys the Spanish version of the call. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: (SPEAKING SPANISH) No, senor! No, senor! No, senor! No, senor!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's the double doink in Espanol. He missed a field goal. Cody Parkey on suicide watch. Poor guy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You think --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I feel bad for him.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You call that -- you think they pulled off a miraculous win? It was more like they failed to lose.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're a big underdog, Dana. Nice try.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I know. I don't know. All right. Gutfeld, what you got?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I haven't done this in a while.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I hate these people!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So for the first time in 26 years or 25 years, I bought a car.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Ooh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I bought a car, and you know what? I hate to say it, nothing has changed. The first time I bought a car from a dealership. So they emailed me, not with one, not with two, not with three, not with four, not with five; six warranties. Six warranties! What in God's name are they trying to do to me? They're trying to kill me with warranties. Warranties for your tires, warranties for your wipers! What happened to the good old full warranty, people? I hate -- I mean, come on! Has nothing changed! What is wrong with you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What kind of car did you get?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm not talking about it. BMW.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Emily, go, go, go.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: All right. So you guys know I used to cheer in the NFL, and I feel very strongly about veterans' causes, so I wanted to draw your attention to this particular organization. It's called Merging Vets and Players, so MVP. And the mission is to match up combat veterans and former pro athletes together after the uniform comes off to give them a new team to tackle the transition together. MVP shows them they are not alone. And this was started by founder Jay Glazer and founder Nate Boyer in 2015.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Awesome.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: And it -- the two core components, physical fitness, peer-to- peer support. Go to VetsandPlayers.org to donate or to refer a combat vet or pro athlete.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next. Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
